passages.text: JPM | Siemens, Novossis, Holcim, NVDA
Today: Ex Dividends: GEN LN, CRDA LN

- Nvidia's earnings report last night might put some pressure on the Data Centre names in Europe this morning (Schneider, Siemens, ABB, Legrand, Prysmian, Nexans) (JPM Basket is JPMEUAIDC) given that Nvidia traded down c3.5% after hours and commentary on BBG highlights decelerating AI related growth. JPM Nvidia take is HERE and our team note that revenue guidance was at the upper end of our expectations with Blackwell/Blackwell Ultra Rack volumes driving the upside. From a Capital Goods Point of view, therefore, we see little in the Nvidia print that undermines the positive growth outlook for Data Centre capex for our European coverage.

- SIEMENS (OW): Phil Buller publishes on Siemens and we move from NR to OW. His 'new' p/t is Eur300. We add the stock to Positive Catalyst Watch. The note is cross asset and incorporates work from our Healthcare team to look at what fundamental fair value is for SHL. We note that Siemens has, over the past decade, closed its conglomerate discount versus peers and this note asks whether it can now start to trade at a premium. With ongoing portfolio simplification likely to be announced at December's CMD (SHL) and the potential for the core 'New Siemens' to outgrow its peers we believe that this is possible. There's a huge amount of work in the note so let me know if you'd like to connect with Phil to go through it. NOTE IS HERE.

- NOVONESIS (OW): Chetan reiterates his OW and highlights that the new OSG targets from last week (6-9%) is best in class in his coverage and that the higher capex is therefore justified. He also notes that the stock is cheaper than it has been over the past couple of years despite growth forecasts being higher. We are encouraged by the breadth of growth opportunities across multiple end markets, as is also reflected in at least HSD% OSG seen across all the key divisions in 1H25. The key mantra remains to stretch the core by leveraging its enviable technological edge (9%+ R&D/sales) and its ability to customize offerings (which also drives higher differentiation and pricing power) to increase penetration of its existing and new products, while also exploring growth from potential new applications/markets. This also partly explains the higher than expected capex/sales guidance of LDD% for the next three years (vs. our previous estimate of \(\sim 10\%\) ) as the company is building a platform to be able to deliver faster growth (up to 9% CAGR) than seen in the past ( \(\sim 6\%\) OSG CAGR over the past 10 years) with an underlying post-tax ROIC of \(>20\%\) . We cut our FY25-28E adj EPS by 4-5%, largely to reflect the incremental FX headwinds and as a result we also trim our Dec 2026 PT to DKK 512 (DKK 545). That said, with a potential 10%+ adj EPS CAGR over the next 3-5 years with high underlying ROIC, we see the recent derating - FY25/26/27E P/E of 28x/26x/24x vs. the historical long-term multiple of \(\sim 30x\) - as an attractive entry point, with our DCF model suggesting an upside potential to DKK 590. Renlain OW. NOTE IS HERE

- HOLCIM (OW): I attended a sell side dinner with the CEO last night and expect analysts to have been reassured by the tone and details of the meeting. Current trading is largely unchanged from the Q2 print although the CEO noted that 'Germany is becoming more confident' - even if they do not expect to see project announcements on the back of the stimulus package until early 2026. The likely debate point from the event revolves around strategy - with the Company indicating it is pursuing acquisitions (could be up to CHF1bn) in light(ish) side materials. It wants to become a solutions provider to the construction industry with an offer of Roofing, Walling, Flooring and Foundational materials alongside the concrete it supplies. Commentary regarding the medium term consolidation of the European cement market was supportive - and, in the near term, the Company expects European pricing to move up in early 2026. We are awaiting the new carbon benchmark from the EU and the Company expects it to be Eur40 or higher which would prompt double digit price increases. Further support comes due to industry consumption of existing carbon credits. Note that these are spec sales views - not yet properly discussed with my research colleagues.

Stadler Rail - Post H1 wrap and model update- Akash Gupta here Following mixed H1 results, we have largely maintained our underlying estimates while an update of exchange rate assumptions leads to a \(1\%\) increase in our 2025 sales and EBIT estimates. Stadler reported mixed H1 results while it updated its 2025 revenue outlook and reiterated its 2026 and medium term targets. Management's indication on FY book- to- bill indicates good commercial activity in H2, but that doesn't fully reconcile with the cash flow view where they expect a neutral cash flow in H2. We maintain our Underweight rating as we remain concerned about execution amid an ongoing industrial ramp up and the knock on impact from floods last year.

J.P. Morgan Global Real Estate - Daily News and Research Summary- Anthony Paolone here Waterton has acquired an apartment complex in Woodland Hills, Los Angeles, from AML1 Residential for \(\) 167.4\(million, The Real Deal reported. The property, developed two decades ago, features 522 - units. The value - add investor plans to renovate the apartments and revamp common areas. Link to the article (subscription required). Related Companies has acquired an apartment complex in Delray Beach, Florida, from Trinsic Residential for\) \ \(116.9\) million (\ \(400K/unit), as reported by South Florida Business Journal. The 292- unit complex was built in 2023 on 11.64 acres. Link to the article (subscription required). Equity Residential has sold a multifamily property in Malden, a Boston suburb, to FPA Multifamily for\) \ \(97\) million (\ \(478K/unit), The Real Deal reported. The 203- unit property last traded in 2003 for \(\) 34.9\(million. The city's most recent assessment of the property pinned its value at\) \ \(70\) million. Link to the article (subscription required). DLJ Real Estate Capital Partners has sold the Nine Orchard hotel in Manhattan's Lower East Side to MML Hospitality for \(\) 92\(million, as reported by the New York Business Journal. The 14 - story hotel opened in 2022 and features 116 rooms, event spaces, and two restaurants. DLJ had owned the site since 2012, purchasing it for\) \ \(5.3\) million. Link to the article (subscription required). American Eagle Outfitters has expanded its office headquarters to 392,185 sf at 63 Madison Avenue in New York City, from landlords George Comfort & Sons, Jamestown and Loeb Partners Realty, Commercial Observer reported. The firm expanded its lease by 54,100 sf. Financial terms of the lease were not disclosed. Link to the article (subscription required). Kohl's Corp. is asking some vendors for more time to settle invoices as the retailer adjusts its payment strategy amid efforts to execute a turnaround plan, as reported by Bloomberg. The retailer aims to standardize its payment terms to align with industry practices, amidst challenges such as declining sales and over \(\) 2\(billion in debt. Link to the article (subscription required).

Novonesis - Attractive entry point for a stock in a league of its own. Stay OW- Chetan Udeshi here The organic sales growth (OSG) CAGR target of \(6 - 9\%\) from 2025 to 2030 that Novonesis (NSISB) management presented last week remains best in class in our coverage. We are encouraged by the breadth of growth opportunities across multiple end markets, as is also reflected in at least HSD% OSG seen across all the key divisions in H2S. The key mantra remains to stretch the core by leveraging its enviable technological edge ( \(9\% +\) R&D/sales) and its ability to customize offerings (which also drives higher differentiation and pricing power) to increase penetration of its existing and new products, while also exploring growth from potential new applications/ markets. This also partly explains the higher than expected capex/sales guidance of LDD% for the next three years (vs. our previous estimate of \(10\%\) ) as the company is building a platform to be able to deliver faster growth (up to \(9\%\) CAGR) than seen in the past ( \(\sim 6\%\) OSG CAGR over the past 10 years) with an underlying post- tax ROIC of \(>20\%\) . We cut our FY25- 28E adj EPS by \(4 - 5\%\) , largely to reflect the incremental FX headwinds and as a result we also trim our Dec 2026 PT to DKK 512 (DKK 545). That said, with a potential \(10\% +\) adj EPS CAGR over the next 3- 5 years with high underlying ROIC, we see the recent derating - FY25/2027E P/E of \(28x / 26x / 24x\) vs. the historical long- term multiple of \(\sim 30x\) - as an attractive entry point, with our DCF model suggesting an upside potential to DKK 590. Remain OW.

Eifage - Results in- line & guidance confirmed; no incremental positives- Elodie Rall here Eifage reported H1 results after market close followed by a Management presentation. Overall results were in line with our expectations, with H1 EBIT at €1,006m (vs JPME at €1,002m) and net income at €308m (JPME €283m, but the difference is driven by surtax phasing where Eifage reported an €83m impact on Net Income in H1 (JPME €116m)). Contracting EBIT was \(2.4\%\) above JPME, driven by Energy, while Concessions EBIT was \(0.7\%\) below our expectations. Order book stood at €29.5bn in Jun- 25 (vs. €28.4bn in Jun- 24), implying order intake levels in Q2 down \(8\% y / y\) (vs. \(- 10\%\) in Q1). Net debt for the period was down at €9.9bn (vs. €10.6bn in Jun- 24), and FCF was - €91m in H1 (vs. €148m in H1 24), driven by a more pronounced seasonal variation in the working capital requirement in Contracting and increased growth investment in Concession, although we note the bulk of FCF is always

generated in H2. Eiffage also confirmed their 2025 guidance. Considering the in line print and unchanged guidance we see limited change to consensus estimates, but expect a marked or slightly negative share price reaction tomorrow given the lack of incremental positives provided, and considered the French political overhang currently
Global Autos Driver - Robotaxi Rides Weekly- Jose M Asumendi here Please find below the latest developments on autonomous driving across the world:

Global Autos Driver - Robotaxi Rides Weekly- Jose M Asumendi here Please find below the latest developments on autonomous driving across the world:Shanghai has introduced a driverless Robotaxi service that provides passengers with connections between Shanghai Disney Resort and Pudong International Airport. The service is operated by IM Motors, SAIC Motor's mobility service platform Xiangdao Chuxing, and SAIC AI Lab, as reported by the Shanghai Observer, citing IM Motors. Passengers can book rides from designated pick- up points through Xiangdao Chuxing's mobile app, with the journey from the resort to Pudong International Airport taking approximately 30 minutes. Since part of the route includes highways, a safety operator will be in the driver's seat. In emergencies, the Robotaxi can be switched to manual mode to allow the operator to take control. Honda Motor Co. has signed a multi- year agreement with US AI startup Helmi.ai Inc. to develop self- driving capabilities. The collaboration aims to produce advanced driver assistance systems for Honda's mass market vehicles by 2027. Mahito Shikama, head of Honda's software defined vehicle business, stated that the joint development supports Honda's goal of realizing safe and affordable automated driving technologies for global customers. Self- driving vehicle startup Nuro closed its latest funding round on Thursday, raising \(203 million at a\) 6 billion valuation from new investors Uber and Nvidia, alongside returning backers. The latest tranche of \(97 million follows the\) 106 million announced in April, which included investors such as T. Rowe Price, Fidelity, and Tiger Global. Nuro has partnered with EV maker Lucid and Uber to launch a global robotaxi service. Uber plans to deploy over 20,000 Lucid Gravity SUVs equipped with Nuro's system across dozens of markets over six years starting in 2026. Kodiak Robotics, an autonomous vehicle technology maker, has integrated NXP Semiconductors' automotive processors and in- vehicle networking interfaces to enhance the performance and reliability of its autonomous trucking system. The partnership, announced Wednesday, incorporates NXP's automotive solutions into the Kodiak Actuation Control Engine (ACE). ACE is Kodiak's custom- built computer that manages vehicle actuation, or more simply, turning the electric or mechanical signals into motion. The integration supports Kodiak's AI- powered autonomous system, known as the Kodiak Driver, and enables the system to execute a safe fallback maneuver and bring the vehicle to a stop if either a safety- critical component or the Kodiak Driver fails. Waymo has started testing its new Robotaxi equipped with sixth- generation self- driving hardware. The new hardware features over 13 cameras, 6 radar systems, and 4 LiDAR sensors onboard according to media platform X, along with a video showcasing the autonomous vehicle in action. The video displays the vehicle driving on the road with a safety driver on board. Additionally, the new Waymo Robotaxi is equipped with heaters, wipers, and sprayers to maintain the cleanliness of the self- driving technology. RoboSense Technology and Hesai Technology, two leading Chinese manufacturers of light detection and ranging sensors, have reported a triple- digit surge in robot product sales last quarter. This segment is beginning to replace advanced driver assistance systems as the main growth driver for both companies. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is investigating delays by Tesla Inc. in reporting details of crashes involving driver- assistance technology. According to NHTSA, the delays were "due to an issue with Tesla's data collection, which, according to Tesla, has now been fixed." NHTSA's Office of Defects Investigation has opened an audit query to assess the cause of the late reports and the mitigation efforts to prevent future occurrences.

Siemens - The 'new Siemens' is not priced in, OW with PT €300- Phil Buller here With the decade- long conglomerate discount versus peers now all but gone, buying Siemens at this point necessitates confidence that the company can sustainably outgrow earnings and/or warrant a premium valuation versus peers. Our analysis suggests both are probable. In this cross- asset and cross- sector note, we explore the prospects for the Siemens AG (SIE) and Siemens Healthineers AG (SHL) equities under different simplification scenarios ahead of an important December 9 CMD, in addition to assessing the impact this would have on credit metrics. We are moving to an OW (from NR) with a Dec- 26 PT of €300 (c30% upside), place the stock on Positive Catalyst Watch into the CMD and add it to our Analyst Focus List.
Use the links below to jump straight to each section: Industrials Overnight Global Industrials Research Global Macro Research
